_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Policy Statement
The Russell Stephenson Wastewater Treatment Facility is committed to being a responsible member of the community in which it operates by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound matter.  Policy dictates that Russell Stephenson WWTF personnel continually identify methods to reduce the use of hazardous materials and to reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation fo new technology and procedures.  This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in the policy and compliance manuals, which are available to all employees.

Description of Facility and Regulated Substances Handled
The County of Okaloosa operates the Russell Stephenson WWTF located at the intersection of Rosewood Drive and US Highway 98 in Mary Esther, Florida.  At the treatment plant, the facility stores approximately four (4) one-ton cylinders of chlorine.  The one-ton cylinders are used on-site as a disinfectant in the treatment of wastewater.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
The Russell Stephenson WWTF is in compliance with the RMP Rule, 40 CFR Part 68.  The facility has conducted a comprehensive review of all systems, as well as administrative, technical, and operating and maintenance procedures, in addition to the other required program elements of the RMP Rule.  A process hazard analysis was conducted at this facility using a "What-if" analysis.

Five Year Accident History
The Russell Stephenson WWTF has not had an accidental release in the last five (5) years.

Emergency Response Program
In the event a significant releases occurs, the Okaloosa County Department of Emergency Services would be notified immediately to respond.  The Department of Emergency Services would dispatch experienced personnel trained to handle such situations.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
It was observed during the process hazard analysis that the Russell Stephenson WWTF h
as the necessary equipment and the operating and training procedures required for the safe operation of the chlorination systems.
